title: Pointless’ Richard Osman feels wrath of Wales after saying it’s ‘not a country’
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Welsh Pointless viewers were left fuming on Saturday afternoon when Richard Osmon stated that Wales isn’t actually a country.

In a celebrity version of the tricky quiz show, a food and drink special edition series saw Matt Tebbutt and Olly Smith among the stars taking on the challenge.

But things went south when asked the competitors were asked for ‘countries with five letters or fewer in their names’.

After thinking about what answer would’ve evaded the studio audience, Matt went for his ‘safe’ option Wales – assuming it would be a high answer but would’ve at least not scored them 100.

But it turned out the Saturday Kitchen presenter was wrong, and Richard Osman told him: ‘United Kingdom is the country I’m afraid.’

Alexander Armstrong then clarified: ‘We are looking for countries, and by countries I mean a sovereign state that is recognised by the United Nations, with five letters or fewer.’

Matt Tebbutt got an unexpected education for the new series (Picture: BBC)

Because United Kingdom is what’s considered a sovereign state, then Wales was wrong.

Naturally viewers, and proud Welsh residents, had something to say about it.

How can you say Wales is not a country @BBCPointlessTV. Actually taking offence to this, the UK is a made up of 4 counties and is not a county itself. What an absolute JOKE. 🤬😤 #pointless — Em (@gnikcoHammE) October 19, 2019

@richardosman Wales is not a country? Try telling the Welsh that. Ps Scotland also a country. We are a union of nations #pointless — Ann Burnett (@Jarmum) October 19, 2019

The controversial ‘wrong’ answer cemented Matt and Olly’s fate and they were ruled out of the game.

Ken Hom and Ching-He Huang, and Candice Brown and Atul Kochhar, also hedged their best and put their general knowledge to the test.

Andi Oliver and Michael O’Hare ended up heading into the final round, but were unable to secure the pointless answer they needed to get the £2,500 prize fund.
